serviceName: Make and register a lasting power of attorney (LPA)
startContent:
This online service will help you to make a lasting power of attorney if you live in England and Wales.

You can make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) using our online service. If you want to, you can ask someone else to help you use the service. For example, a family member or a friend.

Even if you get help, you will still need:

  • your own account to use this service
  • to make all the decisions about what goes on the LPA

There is a different service for charities and solicitors who are supporting someone to make an LPA.

We’ll save the LPA as you progress so you do not need to complete it in one go. You can sign out at any time and come back later.

It costs £82 to apply to register an LPA.

This fee is for the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) to process your application. It includes checking your identity.

An LPA must be registered before it can be used.

Paying for your LPA

You can pay your application fee by card online.

If you have an income below £12,000, or get certain benefits, you might qualify for a lower fee, or the fee might be waived altogether. You can apply to pay a half fee (known as a ‘remission’) or apply to have your fee waived (an ‘exemption’) in the payment section of this service.

If you choose to apply for a remission or an exemption, you’ll need to provide evidence.

Find out more about fees, remissions and exemptions.

What you’ll need

To use this online service, you’ll need:

  • a debit or credit card to pay the fee
  • documents or information to confirm your identity with GOV.UK One Login
  • an email address and a mobile phone, to access GOV.UK One Login
What you need to confirm your identity

When you make an LPA, we need to check your identity. We do this to protect you and prevent fraud. You’ll need to confirm your identity using GOV.UK One Login.

GOV.UK One Login is the new way to access central government services, using the same email address and password. It does not work with all government accounts and services yet. In the future, you’ll be able to use your GOV.UK One Login to access any government service.

You’ll be able to create a GOV.UK One Login if you do not already have one.

Find out more GOV.UK One Login and confirming your identity.

You may also find it useful to gather some information about the people involved in the LPA before you start.

As well as your details, you’ll also need the names, dates of birth and contact details of your attorneys. Find out more about attorneys.

You’ll also need the name and contact details of your certificate provider. Find out more about certificate providers.

whichTypeOfLpaToMake: Which type of LPA do you want to make?
whichTypeOfLpaToMakeContent:
You can have one or both types of LPA. They do not have to be made at the same time. You can choose different people to be your attorneys for each LPA.

Property and affairs LPA

This covers decisions about your money, bills, benefits and home ownership. It can be used as soon as it is registered by the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG), if this is what you decide, even if you still have mental capacity.

Personal welfare LPA

This covers decisions about your day-to-day needs, health care, where you live, and your medical treatment. By law, it can only be used when you have lost mental capacity.

Learn more about the 2 types of LPA.

whoWouldYouLikeToBeTheAttorneysDetailsCo:
Your attorneys are the people who will be able to help you make decisions about your money, property and finances, if you ever want or need their help in the future.

It’s important that you choose people you trust to respect your wishes and act in your best interests. Your attorneys could be:

  • your spouse
  • family members
  • close friends
  • or a professional, like a solicitor

You can have more than one attorney. Most people have between 1 and 3 attorneys.

If you do choose to have more than one attorney, you should choose people who can work well together.

Your attorneys must be aged 18 or over. An attorney must not be bankrupt or have a debt relief order. Find out more about attorneys.

You’ll be asked if you would like to add replacement attorneys in a separate question. They step in if your attorneys are unable or unwilling to continue.

Your attorneys are the people who will be able to help you make decisions about your personal welfare, if you ever need their help in the future.

It’s important that you choose people you trust to respect your wishes and act in your best interests. Your attorneys could be:

whenYourAttorneysCanUseYourLpa: When your attorneys can use your LPA
whenYourAttorneysCanUseYourLpaContent:
You can decide whether you want your attorneys to be able to use your LPA as soon as it’s registered, or only for any decisions you do not have the mental capacity to make for yourself.

Whether or not I have mental capacity to make a particular decision myself

This option means that your attorneys can use your LPA at any time after it is registered, including when you still have mental capacity. For example, if you ask them to make a specific decision for you.

This option is useful in case there are times in the future when you’re able to make your own decisions but need help with certain things. For example, if you are not able to go to the bank or talk on the phone, your attorneys could do these things on your behalf. However, they should not do this without your consent.

Most people choose this option as it’s the most practical.

If you do not have mental capacity

This option means that your attorneys can only use your LPA if you do not have mental capacity to make a particular decision yourself.

Each time they use your LPA, they may be asked to provide proof that you do not have mental capacity to make that decision yourself. This can make it difficult for your attorneys to use your LPA.

restrictionsOnYourAttorneysPowerTitle: Restrict the decisions your attorneys can make
restrictionsOnYourAttorneysPowerContent:
You can limit the decisions your attorneys can make by adding restrictions or conditions to your LPA.

You do not have to add restrictions or conditions to your LPA – this section is optional.

What you say here will tell your attorneys things they:

  • cannot do (‘restrictions’)
  • can only do in certain circumstances (‘conditions’)

If you are not resident in England or Wales, you can use this section to give us information explaining why you are eligible to make an LPA.

There are legal rules about how your restrictions and conditions should be worded, so it’s important to read our guidance on writing restrictions and conditions.

If you’re unsure, or you have detailed restrictions or conditions, you should get legal advice.
restrictionExamplesContent:property-and-:
Example restrictions: things the attorneys cannot do

  • ‘My attorneys cannot sell my home.’

Example conditions: things your attorneys can only do in certain circumstances

  • ‘My attorneys cannot sell my home unless, in an independent professional’s opinion, I can no longer live independently.’
restrictionExamplesContent:personal-welf:
Example restrictions: things the attorneys cannot do

  • ‘My attorneys must not move me into their home.’

Example conditions: things your attorneys can only do in certain circumstances

  • ‘My attorneys can only make the decision to move me to a care home if an independent professional has determined that I can no longer live alone.’
restrictionsHelp: It’s important that you word any restrictions and conditions clearly and carefully.

whatACertificateProviderDoesContent:
A certificate provider is an independent person who checks that you understand your LPA and want to make it. For example, a friend, neighbour or colleague.

Your certificate provider must witness you signing your LPA. They should also read your LPA and talk to you privately about it.

Once they have, they’ll be asked to sign to confirm that, in their opinion:

  • you understand the decisions you’ve made in your LPA and its purpose
  • you are not being pressured to make the LPA by someone else
  • there is no fraud involved in the LPA
  • there’s no other reason your LPA cannot be created

We call this ‘providing a certificate’. Your certificate provider can do this online or using a paper form.
chooseYourCertificateProviderContent:
Your certificate provider must be over 18 years old. They can be someone you know personally, or a professional.

They can be either:

  • someone you’ve known well for at least 2 years - for example, a friend or neighbour (but not a relative)
  • someone with the relevant professional skills to check you understand your LPA and want to make it

  • registered health care professionals
  • barristers, solicitors or advocates in the UK
  • registered social workers

aboutPaymentContent:
It costs £82 to apply to register an LPA.

This fee is for the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) to process your application. It includes checking your identity.

An LPA must be registered before it can be used.

However, you may be able to pay no fee or a half fee, depending on your circumstances.

You may also be able to pay less if you’re making a repeat application.
aboutPaymentNoFeeContent:
No fee

If you receive certain means-tested benefits, you may be eligible to pay no fee. This is called an ‘exemption’.
whoIsEligibleForAnExemption: Who is eligible for an exemption
whoIsEligibleForAnExemptionDetails:
If you receive any of these means-tested benefits you can apply for an exemption:

  • Income Support
  • Income-based Employment and Support Allowance
  • Income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance
  • Guarantee Credit element of State Pension Credit
  • Housing Benefit (housing payments made under Universal Credit are not eligible)
  • Local Housing Allowance
  • Council Tax Reduction or Council Tax Support (but does not include the 25% single-person discount or the Class U exemption for severely mentally impaired people)

You can also apply if you get a combination of Working Tax Credit and at least one of these:

  • Child Tax Credit
  • Disability Element of Working Tax Credit
  • Severe Disability Element of Working Tax Credit

Disability Living Allowance, Invalidity Benefit and Personal Independence Payment are not included.

Exclusion

If you were awarded personal injury damages of more than £16,000 and these were ignored when you were assessed for any of these benefits, you do not qualify for an exemption.
aboutPaymentHalfFeeContent:
Half fee

If your gross annual income is under £12,000 you may be eligible to pay a half fee. This is called a ‘remission’.
payingAHalfFeeBasedOnYourIncome: Paying a half fee based on your income
payingAHalfFeeBasedOnYourIncomeDetails:
If your gross annual income is less than £12,000, you may be eligible for a 50% reduction of the fee. This means you only need to pay half.

Gross annual income is your yearly income before tax.

Your income may come from employment, pensions, Universal Credit, Pension Savings Credit, interest from savings and investments, or the rent of property.

It can also come from non-means-tested benefits, such as:

  • Attendance Allowance
  • Disability Living Allowance
  • Personal Independence Payment

Evidence required

You must send or upload recent proof of your gross annual income to apply for a half fee.

If you receive no income, you must send a signed statement explaining how you support yourself.
aboutPaymentRepeatApplicationContent:
Repeat application discount

If you’ve recently submitted an LPA and it was not registered due to a problem with your form, you may be able to make your new one for free or get a discount.
whoIsEligibleForARepeatApplicationDiscou: Who is eligible for a repeat application discount

To decide if you are eligible for a repeat application discount, the Office of the Public Guardian will have to review your original application.

If you previously qualified to pay no fee (an exemption) or a half fee (a remission), you can apply for these again, but you may need to provide new evidence.
aboutPaymentHardshipContent:
Hardship application

If you’re not eligible to pay a half fee or no fee, but paying for your LPA would cause you to struggle financially, you can make a hardship application to the Public Guardian.

If your hardship application is accepted, your LPA fee will be waived (free).
whatYouNeedToMakeAHardshipApplication: What you need to make a hardship application
whatYouNeedToMakeAHardshipApplicationDet:
‘Hardship’ means that by paying for your LPA you would not be able to meet normal living costs.

To apply, you need to explain why paying would cause you hardship.

You also need to send or upload bank statements and other documents showing all your savings, income and outgoings.

When you sign your LPA, you are forming a legally binding deed that cannot be changed.

If you change your mind about a decision you’ve made in your LPA after you’ve signed it, you’ll need to revoke your LPA and start a new one. You may lose any fee you have paid. Find out more about making changes to an LPA.

If you have any questions or concerns about signing your LPA, you may wish to get legal advice.

yourLegalRightsAndResponsibilitiesConten:
How your attorneys should act

By signing your LPA, you are appointing your attorneys to make decisions for you.

Your attorneys must follow the Mental Capacity Act 2005 (MCA) and the Code of Practice. This includes the principles of the MCA:

  • they must assume you can make your own decisions, unless it is established that you cannot do so
  • they must help you to make as many of your own decisions as you can
  • they must take all practical steps to help you make a decision. They must only treat you as unable to make a decision if they have not succeeded in helping you make a decision through those steps
  • they must not treat you as unable to make a decision because you have made an unwise decision
  • they must act and make decisions in your best interests when you are unable to make a decision
  • before they make a decision or act for you, they must consider any option that is less restrictive of your rights and freedoms which might achieve the same outcome

  • when you sign your LPA, you are making a deed. This is a legal document which officially gives certain powers to your attorneys

  • you can cancel your LPA at any time if you have mental capacity. Find out more about how to cancel your LPA

beACertificateProviderIntroContent:
A certificate provider is an independent person who helps to safeguard the person making the LPA. The person making the LPA is known as the ‘donor’.

The certificate provider checks that the donor understands what they are making and that nobody is putting pressure on them to make an LPA.

They also witness the donor sign their LPA, in person.
whatCertificateProvidersDoContent:
What certificate providers do

Certificate providers should read the LPA and talk to the donor privately about it.

At the time the donor signs their LPA, the certificate provider must form an opinion on whether:

  • the donor understands the decisions they have made in their LPA and the purpose of it
  • the donor is being pressured to make the LPA by someone else
  • there is any fraud involved in the LPA
  • there are any other reasons for concern

If the certificate provider has no concerns, they can sign to confirm this. When they sign, they are providing the certificate for the LPA.

If there is any doubt or the certificate provider has any concerns, they should not provide the certificate for the LPA.
whoCanBeACertificateProviderContent:
Who can be a certificate provider

It’s up to the person making the LPA to choose a certificate provider. Most people ask a friend, neighbour or a colleague.

You can only be a certificate provider if you are over 18 years old and are not related to the donor or their attorneys.

You cannot be a certificate provider if you are already acting as an attorney on the same LPA.

A certificate provider can be either:

  • someone who has known the donor personally for at least 2 years - for example, a friend or neighbour
  • someone with the relevant professional skills and expertise to check the donor understands their LPA and wants to make it

You do not need any legal knowledge to be a certificate provider.

Examples of people who can be a professional certificate provider

People with the relevant professional skills and expertise could include:

  • registered health care professionals
  • barristers, solicitors or advocates in the UK
  • registered social workers
  • independent mental capacity advocates

beAnAttorneyContent:
What is an LPA?

A lasting power of attorney (LPA) is a legal document that lets someone (the ‘donor’) choose one or more trusted people (‘attorneys’) to make decisions on their behalf.

What attorneys do

You can make decisions on someone’s behalf if they appoint you using a lasting power of attorney (LPA).

The person who appoints you is called the ‘donor’. The person acting on the donor’s behalf is called the ‘attorney’.

The decisions you make will be for either the donor’s property and affairs or personal welfare, depending on the type of LPA they’ve made. They can choose you to be an attorney for both.

You do not need any legal experience to act as someone’s attorney but you must understand what the donor’s LPA means and always:

  • act based on the principles of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 and with consideration of the Mental Capacity Act code of practice
  • make any decisions in the donor’s best interests
  • help the donor make their own decisions as much as they can
  • act in the way set out by the donor in their LPA

Find out how to make decisions for someone else including how to get help making difficult decisions and act in someone’s best interests. Your decisions can be checked.

You cannot act as an attorney until the LPA has been registered with the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG).

Who can be an attorney

It’s up to the person making the LPA to choose their attorneys. They can have as many attorneys as they like. If there’s more than one attorney, the donor will state in their LPA how their attorneys should make decisions.

Attorneys must:

  • be aged 18 or over
  • not be on the Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) barred list (unless you are a family member and you are not getting paid a fee to be an attorney)
  • not be a subject to an ongoing bankruptcy order or a debt relief order (for a property and financial affairs LPA only)

A Trust Corporation can also act as an attorney.

Replacement attorneys

The person making an LPA can choose people to step in if one of their attorneys can no longer act. The OPG must be told if this happens so the LPA can be updated and can continue to be used.

Before you start

If you’ve been asked to be someone’s attorney, you’ll need:

  • to sign in using GOV.UK One Login (the new way to sign in to all government services)
  • to provide some of your details, so we can check they match the information the donor has provided

If you’ve not used GOV.UK One Login before, you can set up your account on the next page.

attorneyCodeOfConduct:property-and-affai:
As a property and affairs attorney, you’ll have the power to make decisions about the donor’s ({{possessive .DonorFullName}}) money and property. This could include managing bank accounts, bills and benefits, and selling property.

Before agreeing to become {{possessive .DonorFirstNames}} attorney, it’s important to understand how you should act when using the LPA to make decisions.

You must follow the principles of the Mental Capacity Act (2005) and the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice.

This includes:

  • making sure that your decisions are in the best interests of the donor
  • not benefiting from any decisions you make
  • supporting the donor to make their own decisions wherever possible
  • making decisions yourself unless the donor has said otherwise
  • follow any restrictions the donor put in their LPA
  • consider any conditions the donor put in their LPA
  • respecting the donor’s confidentiality
  • keeping records of the donor’s money and property - your decisions can be checked
  • keeping the donor’s money and property separate from your own

When you can no longer act as an attorney

If you misuse the donor’s money and they become bankrupt, you will no longer be able to act as their attorney.

attorneyRightsAndResponsibilitiesContent:
Before signing, you must read your legal rights and responsibilities as an attorney.

How attorneys should act

When the donor signs their LPA, they are appointing their attorneys to make decisions for them.

As an attorney, you must follow the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice:

  • You must assume the donor can make their own decisions, unless it is established that they cannot do so.
  • You must help the donor to make as many of their own decisions as they can.
  • You must take all practical steps to help the donor make a decision. You must only treat the donor as unable to make a decision if you have not succeeded in helping the donor make a decision through those steps.
  • You must not treat the donor as unable to make a decision because they have made an unwise decision.
  • You must act and make decisions in the donor’s best interests when they are unable to make a decision.
  • Before you make a decision or act for the donor, you must consider any option that is less restrictive of the donor’s rights and freedom which might achieve the same outcome.

How this LPA can be used

  • When the donor signs their LPA, along with all their attorneys, replacement attorneys and certificate provider, they are forming a legal agreement (a deed).
  • This LPA can only be used if it’s registered with the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG).
  • The donor can cancel their LPA at any time if they have mental capacity.
  • You, or any other attorney named in this LPA, cannot use the LPA to make changes to the donor’s will.
  • This LPA will expire when the donor dies.
trustCorporationRightsAndResponsibilitie:
Before signing, you must read the trust corporation’s legal rights and responsibilities as an attorney.

  • It must assume the donor can make their own decisions, unless it is established that they cannot do so.
  • It must help the donor to make as many of their own decisions as they can.
  • It must take all practical steps to help the donor make a decision. It must only treat the donor as unable to make a decision if it has not succeeded in helping the donor make a decision through those steps.
  • It must not treat the donor as unable to make a decision because they have made an unwise decision.
  • It must act and make decisions in the donor’s best interests when they are unable to make a decision.
  • Before it makes a decision or acts for the donor, it must consider any option that is less restrictive of the donor’s rights and freedom which might achieve the same outcome.
  • It must not be going through winding-up proceedings.
  • It can spend money to make gifts but only to charities or customary occasions such as birthdays, and for reasonable amounts with regard to size of the donor’s estate.
  • It has a duty to keep accounts and financial records and produce them to the Office of the Public Guardian or to the Court of Protection on request.

  • Income Support
  • Income-based Employment and Support Allowance

  • Guarantee Credit element of State Pension Credit
  • Housing Benefit
  • Local Housing Allowance
  • Council Tax Reduction or Council Tax Support (does not include the 25% single-person discount or the Class U exemption for severely mentally impaired people)

  • Child Tax Credit
  • Disability Element of Working Tax Credit
  • Severe Disability Element of Working Tax Credit

Disability Living Allowance, Invalidity Benefit and Personal Independence Payment are not included.

Personal injury damages exclusion

If you were awarded personal injury damages of more than £16,000 and these were ignored when you were assessed for any of these benefits, you do not qualify for an exemption.

This online service is for professionals who help people to make LPAs.

  • independent estate planner

In the future, it will allow you to access any government service using the same email address and password.

It does not work with all GOV.UK services yet.

Setting up your GOV.UK One Login

If you’re creating LPAs as part of an organisation, we recommend using your work email address when setting up your GOV.UK One Login to access this service.

What if I already have a GOV.UK One Login?

If you’ve already created a GOV.UK One Login with a personal email address, you can still use it to access this service.

However, it may become difficult to separate your personal LPAs from the LPAs you are drafting on behalf of other people.

For this reason, we recommend creating a separate GOV.UK One Login with your work email address, if you have one.

yourLegalRightsAndResponsibilitiesIfYouM: Your legal rights and responsibilities if you make an LPA

This service will guide you through making an LPA. When you sign the LPA, you will need to agree to legal rights and responsibilities. You must have mental capacity and be over the age of 18 to make an LPA.

You should read your legal rights and responsibilities before you start. This can help you understand how your attorneys must act and how your LPA can be used once it’s registered.

How your attorneys should act

By signing your LPA, you are appointing your attorneys to make decisions for you.

Your attorneys must follow the Mental Capacity Act 2005 (MCA) and the Code of Practice (opens in new tab). This includes the principles of the MCA:

  • They must assume you can make your own decisions, unless it is established that you cannot do so.
  • They must help you to make as many of your own decisions as you can.
  • They must take all practical steps to help you make a decision. They must only treat you as unable to make a decision if they have not succeeded in helping you make a decision through those steps.
  • They must not treat you as unable to make a decision because you have made an unwise decision.
  • They must act and make decisions in your best interests when you are unable to make a decision.
  • Before they make a decision or act for you, they must consider any option that is less restrictive of your rights and freedoms which might achieve the same outcome

How your LPA can be used

  • When you sign your LPA, you are making a deed. This is a legal document which officially gives certain powers to your attorneys.
  • Your LPA can only be used once it is registered with the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG).
  • You can cancel your LPA at any time if you have mental capacity. Find out more about how to cancel your LPA (opens in new tab).
  • Your attorneys cannot use your LPA to make changes to your will.
  • Your LPA will expire when you die.

This accessibility statement applies to Make and register a lasting power of attorney.

This website is run by the Office of the Public Guardian. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website. For example, that means you should be able to:

  • zoom in up to 400% without the text spilling off the screen
  • navigate most of the website using a keyboard or speech recognition software
  • listen to most of the website using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)

Feedback and contact information

addingRestrictionsAndConditionsToTheLPA: Adding restrictions and conditions to the LPA
addingRestrictionsAndConditionsToTheLPAC:
The donor can limit the decisions their attorneys can make by adding restrictions and conditions to their LPA.

Restrictions set out what the donor’s attorneys can and cannot do. Conditions set out what the donor’s attorneys can and cannot do in particular circumstances.

Restrictions and conditions are optional. As an alternative, the donor could choose to explain their wishes to their attorneys, and trust them to act in their best interests. However, this would not be legally binding.

Restrictions and conditions must be carefully planned and worded so they don’t contradict other parts of the LPA. The donor should take legal advice if they’re worried about the correct way to phrase them.

Examples of valid restrictions and conditions

Understanding mental capacity gives examples of how the donor can use restrictions and conditions to control how their mental capacity is assessed.

Understanding life-sustaining treatment (LST) gives examples of how the donor can use restrictions and conditions to control how they receive LST.

How decisions are made in LPAs with more than one attorney gives examples of how the donor can use restrictions and conditions to control how their attorneys make decisions.

Information about replacement attorneys gives examples of how the donor can use restrictions and conditions to control how their replacement attorneys step in.

Restrictions and conditions to avoid

The donor should avoid restrictions or conditions that could be against their best interests in future.

For example, if the donor states that their attorneys must not move them into a care home, and the donor then needs that care, they would have to apply to the Court of Protection for permission. This costs £408 and could take several months.

The donor cannot include restrictions and conditions that state their money is to be used to benefit or maintain other people.

For example, they can’t write restrictions to arrange:

  • trust funds for grandchildren
  • payment of school fees for grandchildren
  • interest-free loans to family
  • maintenance for any family member other than their wife, husband, civil partner or child under 18

Restrictions like these will be invalid as they could stop their attorneys from acting in their best interests. The donor’s attorneys must apply to the Court of Protection if they want to make gifts like this on their behalf.

Small customary cash gifts to mark special occasions are permitted, if the donor’s budget allows and the sum is reasonable. Check guidance on gifting (opens in new tab) for more information.

Common mistakes when writing restrictions and conditions

The donor should take care not to ask for something the law won’t allow. For example, they cannot:

  • change how their attorneys make decisions, for example from jointly to jointly and severally
  • set restrictions or conditions for specific attorneys – they apply to all of them
  • tell their attorneys to do anything against the law, even if it could be legal in the future, for example assisted dying
  • tell an attorney to act in anyone else’s best interests – they act for the donor alone
  • appoint replacement attorneys to act temporarily, for example if an attorney is ill
  • tell an attorney to change their will – it’s outside their powers
  • give an attorney permission to appoint more attorneys
  • write restrictions or conditions for another type of LPA, for example, writing restrictions about their finances in their personal welfare LPA

Restrictions and conditions are legally enforceable

If the donor decides to add restrictions and conditions, they should bear in mind that, if correctly worded, they are legally enforceable. If their attorneys acted against the restrictions and conditions, they could be taken to court.

The donor may wish to seek legal advice before adding any restrictions and conditions.

howMultipleAttorneysMakeDecisionsContent:
If the donor has more than one attorney or replacement attorney, they must decide how they want their attorneys to make decisions.

The 3 options are explained below, with examples of how each option could work. If the donor is not sure which is best for their circumstances, they may want to get legal advice.

Bear in mind that, for every option, all the attorneys are legally responsible for every decision that is made on the donor’s behalf. This means that if the attorneys cannot collaborate together, the LPA will not work.

Adding restrictions and conditions

Restrictions and conditions can be used to modify the way the attorneys make decisions.

The restrictions and conditions on this page are just examples – the donor should write them to suit their own needs.

Restrictions and conditions must be carefully planned and worded so they don’t contradict other parts of the LPA. The donor should take legal advice if they’re worried about the correct way to phrase them.

Jointly and severally: attorneys make decisions both together or on their own

Your attorneys can divide up tasks and responsibilities when making decisions on your behalf.

It’s up to your attorneys to decide if they want to make a decision as a group (‘jointly’) or on their own (‘severally’), but the decisions they make must always be in your best interests.

Remember that all the attorneys are responsible for all decisions, even those taken by an attorney on their own.

For example, an attorney might decide to book the donor into an expensive hair salon without consulting their fellow attorneys. They must be confident that this decision is in the donor’s best interests, and would be supported by their fellow attorneys, as they will also be held responsible for it.

Another example might be an attorney who is better at managing money and takes the lead on financial decisions, making them on their own. The other attorneys will still be held responsible for these decisions – claiming ignorance of them is not a defence.

Most people choose ‘jointly and severally’ because:

  • attorneys can make simple or urgent decisions quickly and easily, without asking the donor’s other attorneys
  • if an attorney can no longer act, the LPA will not be cancelled

Jointly: attorneys must agree and act together on every decision

The attorneys must agree and must act together (‘jointly’) on all decisions, however big or small. For example, if money needs to be withdrawn from a bank, not only must all attorneys agree with this decision, but they must also be physically present when the money is withdrawn.

With this option:

  • meetings to discuss the donor’s care must take place with all the attorneys physically present
  • the attorneys may not be able to use internet or telephone banking to manage the donor’s bank accounts or pay bills
  • if the attorneys live far apart, they may find acting jointly impractical – for example, going to the bank together
  • if the attorneys fall out or one moves abroad, the LPA would not longer work

Restrictions and conditions on attorneys acting jointly

The law treats attorneys who act jointly as a single unit. This means that if an attorney dies or is unable or unwilling to act, the LPA will stop working.

However, the donor can add restrictions and conditions to change this.

For instance, the donor can state that if one of the joint attorneys can no longer act, the remaining joint attorneys can continue to make all decisions.

Example restriction:

‘If one of my original joint attorneys, Jane Taylor or Robert Smith, is unable or unwilling to act, I then reappoint my remaining original attorney, Jane Taylor or Robert Smith, as attorney.’

Jointly for some decisions, and jointly and severally for others: attorneys must agree and act together for some decisions

The attorneys must agree and must act together (‘jointly’) on some decisions, but are able to make other decisions on their own (‘jointly and severally’). If you choose this option, you must clearly state which decisions your attorneys should make together and all agree on: that is, when they should act ‘jointly’.

Remember that even when attorneys take decisions ‘on their own’, they must be confident they are in the donor’s best interests and would therefore have the support of the other attorneys.

With this option:

  • the donor specifies which decisions must be agreed and acted on together, with all attorneys physically present
  • for those decisions the donor specifies can be made by attorneys acting together or on their own, the attorneys will not need to be physically present

Restrictions and conditions on attorneys acting jointly for some decisions and jointly and severally for others

If an attorney dies or is unable or unwilling to act, the remaining attorneys will not be able to make any of the joint decisions, unless the donor has said otherwise in their restrictions and conditions.

For instance, the donor can state that if one of their attorneys can no longer act, the remaining attorneys can continue to make all the joint decisions.

Example restriction:

‘If one of my original attorneys, Jane Taylor or Robert Smith, is unable or unwilling to act, I then reappoint my remaining original attorney, Jane Taylor or Robert Smith, to continue to make the decisions I have instructed should be made jointly.’

If the donor has also appointed replacement attorneys, the donor could add further restrictions.

Example restriction:

‘If one of my replacement attorneys, Anne Brown or Chris Wilson, is unable or unwilling to act, I then reappoint my remaining replacement attorney, Anne Brown or Chris Wilson, to continue to make the decisions I have instructed should be made jointly.’

Property and affairs restrictions and conditions on attorneys acting jointly for some decisions and jointly and severally for others

In these examples, ‘everything else’ means all other decisions about the donor’s property and affairs:

‘My attorneys must act jointly in relation to decisions about selling or letting my house and may act jointly and severally for everything else.’

‘My attorneys must act jointly in relation to decisions about investments in stocks and shares and may act jointly and severally for everything else.’

Personal welfare restrictions and conditions on attorneys acting jointly for some decisions and jointly and severally for others

Example restrictions:

‘My attorneys must act jointly in relation to decisions about where I live and may act jointly and severally for everything else.’

‘My attorneys must act jointly in relation to decisions I have authorised them to make about life-sustaining treatment and may act jointly and severally for everything else.’

As the donor, you must be careful not to set restrictions and conditions that contradict your decisions about life-sustaining treatment (LST).

For example, you cannot decide that your attorneys cannot make decisions about LST, then add a restriction that says your attorneys must make LST decisions jointly.

Resolving disputes between attorneys

The donor should choose attorneys who work well together and can be trusted to act in the donor’s best interest. The donor should also share their wishes with the attorneys when they make their LPA.

In the event that the attorneys cannot agree, they can contact The Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) for advice.

If an agreement cannot be reached, attorneys must apply to the Court of Protection. Formal resolution of a dispute through the court can be expensive and lengthy.

howToSelectAttorneysForAnLPAContent:
When the donor makes an LPA, they choose one or more trusted people to make decisions (‘act’) on their behalf. These people are called attorneys.

The donor must choose at least 1 attorney. They can have as many attorneys as they want, but if there are too many, it may be difficult for them to all work together.

When making decisions for the donor, the attorneys must always:

  • act in the donor’s best interests
  • follow any restrictions and conditions the donor puts in their LPA
  • follow the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice (opens in new tab)

Choosing attorneys

Anyone aged 18 or over who has mental capacity can be an attorney.

The donor should choose people they trust to act in their best interests. Attorneys do not need to be solicitors or have a legal background – many donors choose family members or close friends.

However, the donor can also ask a solicitor or other type of professional to act as their attorney, usually for a fee.

A person who is on the Disclosure and Barring Service barred list cannot act as a paid attorney. They’re breaking the law if they do.

An undischarged bankrupt or a person subject to a debt relief order cannot be an attorney for a property and affairs LPA.

It’s important that:

  • the attorneys understand the donor’s beliefs and preferences well enough to make decisions for the donor
  • the attorneys work well together
  • the donor trusts their attorneys to act in their best interests
  • the attorneys have the skills to act under the LPA – for example, do they manage their own affairs well?

The donor should fully discuss the LPA with their potential attorneys before appointing them. Being an attorney can be a lot of work.

Potential attorneys can visit Acting as an attorney (opens in new tab) to find out more about what’s involved.

Appointing the donor’s wife, husband or civil partner as an attorney

The donor can appoint their wife, husband or civil partner as an attorney. This person will usually have to stop being an attorney if the marriage or civil partnership is later ended. If they’re the only attorney and there are no replacement attorneys, this means the LPA can no longer be used.

However, the donor can add restrictions and conditions stating that their wife, husband or civil partner can continue to be their attorney after a divorce, dissolution or annulment.

Professional attorneys

Some donors ask a professional, such as a solicitor or accountant, to be their attorney or one of their attorneys. Professional attorneys usually charge fees.

If the donor appoints a professional attorney, they must name an individual in the LPA. They cannot just give a job title or the name of a firm.

Trust corporations

A trust corporation can be the attorney or one of the attorneys on a property and financial affairs LPA. A trust corporation manages funds, such as savings, pensions and investments. It’s usually run by a commercial bank or firm of solicitors.

If the donor’s finances are complex or they do not have anyone they want to appoint as an attorney, they might choose a trust corporation. If they’re considering this, the donor should get legal or financial advice.

If the donor appoints a trust corporation as their attorney, they must make sure they use the exact name it operates under in the LPA.

The donor can only appoint one trust corporation in their LPA.

When attorneys can no longer act

An attorney can no longer act if they:

  • lose mental capacity
  • decide they no longer want to act as an attorney (known as ‘disclaiming their appointment’)
  • were the donor’s wife, husband or civil partner, but the relationship has legally ended (unless the donor states otherwise in their restrictions and conditions)
  • become bankrupt or subject to a debt relief order and were an attorney for a property and financial affairs LPA
  • are paid to act as an attorney, and are placed on the Disclosure and Barring Service barred list

When an attorney dies or can no longer act, the LPA will be cancelled if:

  • the donor only appointed one attorney and no replacement attorneys
  • the donor appointed the attorneys jointly and did not appoint any replacements, unless the donor specified otherwise in their restrictions and conditions

If the donor cancels their LPA, the attorneys can no longer act on the donor’s behalf.

Remove an attorney after the LPA has been registered

As long as the donor still has mental capacity, they can contact OPG and ask for a particular attorney to be removed from their LPA.

Concerns about attorneys

The Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) does not supervise attorneys. However, you can raise a concern with OPG (opens in new tab) if you believe an attorney is not acting in the donor’s best interests. OPG or other organisations, such as the police or social services, may investigate.
replacementAttorneysContent:
Replacement attorneys are people the donor chooses to step in if one of their original attorneys can no longer act.

The donor does not have to appoint replacement attorneys, but having them helps to protect the LPA. It means the LPA should still work if an original attorney can no longer act.

Without replacements:

  • if there’s only one attorney and that attorney can no longer act, the LPA will stop working
  • if the donor appointed their attorneys to act jointly and one attorney can no longer act, the LPA will stop working, unless the donor has stated otherwise in their restrictions and conditions
  • if the donor appointed their attorneys to act jointly for some decisions, and one attorney can no longer act, the joint decisions can no longer be made, unless the donor has stated otherwise in their restrictions and conditions

If the LPA cannot be used and the donor no longer has mental capacity, someone will have to apply to the Court of Protection to become a ‘deputy’ – meaning they are given the power by the court to act on the donor’s behalf.

This can be expensive and usually takes a long time. If appointed, the deputy must report to the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) every year, as well as pay an annual fee.

Who can be a replacement attorney

A replacement attorney must meet the same requirements as an original attorney. This includes having mental capacity and being 18 or over when the donor signs the LPA.

The donor should choose their replacements as carefully as they choose their original attorneys.

The difference between replacement attorneys and multiple attorneys

A replacement attorney cannot start to make decisions until after one of your original attorneys can no longer act.

This means a replacement attorney is a back-up for your LPA, a way to ensure it keeps working if your original attorneys can no longer make decisions on your behalf.

When replacement attorneys can act

Replacement attorneys cannot act without the authorisation of the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG). If one of the donor’s original attorneys can no longer act, OPG must be contacted to amend the LPA accordingly.

A replacement attorney cannot temporarily stand in for an attorney who is still able to act (for example, while the first attorney is on holiday).

There are a number of reasons why an attorney can no longer act. The attorney may:

  • die
  • lose mental capacity
  • decide they no longer want to act as an attorney (known as ‘disclaiming their appointment’)
  • be the donor’s wife, husband or civil partner, but the relationship has legally ended and the donor has not stated in their restrictions and conditions that their ex-partner can continue as an attorney in these circumstances
  • become bankrupt or subject to a debt relief order as an attorney for a property and financial affairs LPA

Replacing attorneys who act jointly and severally

When the original attorneys are appointed to act jointly and severally and an original attorney dies or can no longer act:

  • all the replacement attorneys will step in together, unless the donor has stated otherwise in their restrictions and conditions
  • the replacement attorneys and any remaining original attorneys can then make decisions jointly and severally

Examples of restrictions and conditions to change when and how replacement attorneys step in

When the original attorneys are appointed to act jointly and severally, the donor can add restrictions and conditions to specify the order in which their replacement can step in. This is optional.

Examples:

‘If one of my attorneys (either my mother Jane Brown or my father John Brown) can no longer act, I would like that attorney to be replaced by my sister Sarah Smith, who is one of my replacement attorneys. If later on my other parent can no longer act, I would like my other replacement attorney, my brother Michael Brown, to step in to replace that person as my attorney.’

‘If my attorney Dave Smith becomes unable to act under this LPA, I want replacement attorney Jane Hall to step in and act in his place.’

Replacing attorneys who act jointly

Replacement attorneys are an important backup when attorneys are appointed to act jointly.

When there are replacement attorneys, if an original attorney dies or can no longer act:

  • all the replacement attorneys will replace all the original attorneys
  • the remaining original attorneys will not be able to make any decisions on the donor’s behalf anymore

Examples of restrictions and conditions to change what happens when a joint attorney dies or is unable to act

If the original attorneys are appointed jointly, the donor can add restrictions and conditions to change what happens when an original attorney dies or is unable or unwilling to act.

Example:

‘If one of my original joint attorneys, Jane Doe or John Doe, is unable or unwilling to act, I then reappoint my remaining original attorney(s), Jane Doe or John Doe, as a replacement attorney.’

Replacing attorneys who act jointly for some decisions

Replacement attorneys are an important backup when attorneys are appointed to act jointly for some decisions, and jointly and severally for others.

When there are replacement attorneys, if an attorney dies or can no longer act:

  • all the replacement attorneys step in and take over making the joint decisions
  • the remaining original attorneys will not be able to make the joint decisions anymore
  • the replacement and remaining original attorneys can make all other decisions individually

Examples of restrictions and conditions to change what happens when an attorney who acts jointly for some decisions dies or is unable to act

If the original attorneys are appointed jointly for some decisions, the donor can add restrictions and conditions to change what happens when an original attorney dies or is unable or unwilling to act.

Examples:

‘If one of my original attorneys, David Smith or Andrea Williams, is unable or unwilling to act, I then reappoint my remaining original attorney(s), David Smith or Andrea Williams, to continue to make the decisions I have specified to be jointly made.’

‘If one of my replacement attorneys, Margaret Taylor or Nick Brown, is unable or unwilling to act, I then reappoint my remaining replacement attorney(s), Margaret Taylor or Nick Brown, to continue to make the decisions I have specified to be jointly made.’
theTwoTypesOfLPAContent:
There are 2 types of LPA:

  • property and affairs
  • personal welfare

The person making the LPA is called the donor. The donor can have one or both types of LPA. The LPAs do not have to be made at the same time and the donor can choose different attorneys for each LPA.

The 2 types of LPA are separate – you cannot make an LPA which covers both property and affairs and personal welfare.

Property and affairs LPA

This LPA type covers decisions about the donor’s money, bills, benefits and home ownership.

The donor does not have to own their own home or have a lot of money to make this type of LPA.

Decisions attorneys for a property and affairs LPA can make

The donor chooses people they trust (attorneys) to make decisions on their behalf in their best interests. The decisions cover money and financial matters, including, but not limited to:

  • opening, closing and using their bank or building society accounts
  • claiming, receiving and using their benefits, pensions and allowances
  • paying household and other bills
  • buying and selling their house
  • managing their property and investments

Ideally, a donor’s money should be kept separate from their attorneys’ money.

The donor can also make a separate LPA for their business affairs if they want different people to make those decisions.

When a property and affairs LPA can be used

When they make their LPA, the donor can decide when it can be used. For a property and affairs LPA, this can either be as soon as it’s registered, or only when the donor lacks mental capacity.

Personal welfare LPA

This LPA type covers decisions about the donor’s day-to-day needs, health care, where they live, and their medical treatment.

Decisions attorneys for a personal welfare LPA can make

The donor chooses people they trust (attorneys) to make decisions about things including, but not limited to:

  • giving or refusing consent to particular types of health care, including medical treatment
  • getting help and support from social services
  • where the donor lives – for example, whether the donor stays in their own home or moves into a care home
  • finding a good care home or care providers
  • day-to-day matters like the donor’s diet, dress or daily routine
  • managing their property and investments

A personal welfare attorney might need to spend the donor’s money on things that maintain or improve the donor’s quality of life. This can include:

  • hairdressing or new clothes
  • decorating the donor’s home or room in a care home
  • paying for extra support so the donor can go out more, for example to visit relatives or to go on holiday

The attorney must ask for money from the person in charge of the donor’s funds. In some cases, the same person may be an attorney on both the donor’s property and affairs LPA and their personal welfare LPA.

When a personal welfare LPA can be used

This type of LPA can only be used after it’s been registered and if the donor does not have the mental capacity to make decisions.

Life-sustaining treatment

‘Life-sustaining treatment’ is medical treatment needed to keep someone alive.

In their personal welfare LPA, the donor must choose whether their attorneys can give or refuse consent to life-sustaining treatment on their behalf.

Learn more about life-sustaining treatment.
understandingLifeSustainingTreatmentCont:
The donor must choose whether their attorneys can give or refuse consent to life-sustaining treatment (LST) on their behalf.

LST means care, surgery, medicine or other help from doctors that’s needed to keep someone alive. It could include:

  • a serious operation, such as a heart bypass or organ transplant
  • cancer treatment
  • food or water given to you that you cannot take yourself
  • antibiotics for a life-threatening infection

If attorneys have authority to decide on LST

If the donor chooses to give their attorneys the authority to give or refuse consent to LST, their attorneys will be able to talk to medical professionals on their behalf as if they were the donor.

The donor can add restrictions and conditions setting out when and if they receive LST and the attorneys can share these with doctors. However, medical professionals cannot be forced to adopt a particular treatment approach if they think it unsuitable.

The donor does not have to add any restrictions and conditions for LST – their attorneys can act in their best interests without them.

Examples of restrictions and conditions on LST

Example of a restriction on LST:

‘My attorneys must consult my family when making decisions about life-sustaining treatment.’

Example of a condition on LST:

‘If I were in the last days of a terminal illness, I would only want treatments to make me comfortable. I would not want treatments to prolong my life or that meant I could not die at home.’

Learn more about restrictions and conditions (opens in a new tab).

If attorneys do not have authority to decide on LST

If the donor chooses not to give their attorneys the authority to give or refuse consent to LST, their attorneys will not be able to talk to medical professionals on their behalf as if they were the donor.

However, medical professionals will always act in the best interests of their patients, consulting their attorneys and family members to decide what is best for the individual.

They will also take into account any advance decision (opens in a new tab) the donor has made.

If the donor has made an ‘advance decision’

An advance decision to refuse treatment is a legally binding written statement. It lets someone say what medical treatment they do not want to have in certain situations in the future. It’s sometimes called a ‘living will’.

The donor can have an advance decision and an LPA. However, they may want to get legal advice to check these documents do not contradict each other.

The NHS has more information about advance decisions (opens in new tab).

There’s more information about LST, advance decisions and how health professionals must respond to someone’s written wishes in chapter 9 of the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice (opens in new tab).
understandingMentalCapacityContent:
A person with mental capacity is able to make a specific decision at the time it needs to be made. They will have at least some understanding of:

  • the decision they need to make
  • why they need to make it
  • any information relevant to the decision
  • what is likely to happen when they make it

They should be able to communicate their decision through speech, signs or in other ways.

Mental capacity is not always fixed

A person may have the mental capacity to make some decisions but not others. For example, they may be able to decide what to buy for dinner but be unable to understand and arrange their home insurance.

If someone’s condition changes day-to-day, there may be times when they have mental capacity to make a decision and times when they do not.

A person can also temporarily lack mental capacity, for example if they are unconscious.

Assessing mental capacity

If the donor decides that their LPA can only be used when they lose mental capacity, this will need to be assessed by their attorneys, or more formally, by a professional.

To work out whether someone lacks the mental capacity to make a decision, they must be assessed at the time the particular decision needs to be made.

The person assessing the donor’s mental capacity needs to answer ‘yes’ to the following 2 questions:

1. Does the donor have a condition that affects the way their brain or mind works?

2. Does this mean they are unable to make a specific decision at the time it needs to be made?

Being ‘unable to make a specific decision’ means that the person can’t:

  • understand relevant information about the decision that needs to be made
  • keep that information in their mind long enough to make the decision
  • weigh up the information in order to make the decision
  • communicate their decision – this could be by talking, using sign language or even simple muscle movements such as blinking an eye or squeezing a hand

The 5 principles of the Mental Capacity Act 2005

When acting or making decisions on the donor’s behalf, attorneys must follow the 5 main principles of the Mental Capacity Act. They must:

  • presume the donor has capacity to make decisions
  • support the donor to make decisions themselves
  • not assume that if the donor makes an unwise decision it means they lack mental capacity – everyone has the right to make decisions that others might think are unwise
  • act in the donor’s best interests
  • where possible, choose options that give the donor the more freedom or choice

Restrictions and conditions on assessing mental capacity

The donor can use restrictions and conditions to set out how their mental capacity should be assessed. However, these are optional. If the donor trusts their attorneys to assess their mental capacity, they do not need to add restrictions and conditions.

Remember that your restrictions and conditions cannot contradict other instructions. So, for example, if you’ve decided that your property and affairs LPA can be used as soon as it is registered, you cannot then set a restriction stating that it can only be used when you have lost mental capacity.

Examples of restrictions on how mental capacity should be assessed:

‘My attorneys shall only act under the power of this property and affairs LPA if they have obtained a written medical opinion stating that I am no longer mentally capable of managing and administering my property and financial affairs.’

‘This personal welfare lasting power of attorney only applies if my GP or another doctor confirms in writing that I do not have capacity to make specific decisions about my medical treatment.’

The Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice

The Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice (opens in new tab) has more information about caring for people who can’t make decisions for themselves.

glossaryIntroContent:
This page explains some of the words the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) uses in Make and register a lasting power of attorney (LPA).

You’ll find links to more guidance as you go through the process of making an LPA.
glossary:A:
Advance decision

An advance decision to refuse treatment lets someone’s healthcare team know their wishes if they are not able to communicate them. It is sometimes known as an advance decision to refuse treatment, an ADRT, or a living will.

An advance decision is a legally binding document in which an individual states which life-sustaining treatments they do not want, in case they cannot make their wishes known in the future. Learn more about how to create an advance decision document (opens in new tab).

Attorney

Attorneys are people the donor appoints in their LPA to make decisions on their behalf. Attorneys should be people the donor knows well and trusts.

Attorneys do not need to be lawyers. Many people choose their wife, husband, civil partner, partner, children, other relatives or close friends. Attorneys must be at least 18 years old.

Learn more about choosing attorneys.

Authorised signatory

If a donor cannot sign their LPA due to disability, they can appoint an authorised signatory to sign on their behalf.
glossary:C:
Certificate provider

Certificate providers are impartial people who confirm that the donor understands what they are doing and that nobody is forcing them to make the LPA. An LPA must have a certificate provider.

Confirming identity

The Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) will not be able to register an LPA until the donor and certificate provider have confirmed their identity.

Donors and certificate providers can use the GOV.UK One Login service to confirm their identity either online, or at a Post Office. They will need an identity document, for example:

  • a payslip, P60 or a benefits letter
  • a UK passport
  • a UK driving licence

If the donor is unable to confirm their identity using GOV.UK One Login, they’ll be given guidance on how to confirm it using vouching. A certificate provider cannot confirm their identity using vouching

Correspondent

The donor can nominate a correspondent to be contacted by the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) about the progress of the LPA.

The correspondent can be one of the donor’s attorneys, or someone else, such as a solicitor.

Court of protection

Some LPAs may need to be reviewed by the Court of Protection before they can be registered by the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) – usually because a donor or certificate provider has had difficulty confirming their identity.

If this is the case, it is the donor’s responsibility to submit their LPA to the Court of Protection. It costs £408 to get an LPA reviewed by the Court of Protection and takes several months.
glossary:D:
Deadlines

Once an LPA has been signed by the donor and submitted to the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG), it must be signed by the certificate provider and attorneys within 2 years.

Additionally, the donor must:

  • confirm their identity within 6 months of signing their LPA – otherwise the LPA expires
  • sign their LPA within 6 months of confirming their identity – otherwise they will have reconfirm their identity

The certificate provider must:

  • confirm their identity within 6 months of signing the LPA

The donor has the option of getting their LPA reviewed by the Court of Protection if:

  • the donor tries and fails to confirm their identity within 6 months of signing the LPA
  • the certificate provider fails to confirm their identity within 6 months of signing the LPA

The Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) will send the donor, certificate provider and attorneys reminders about these deadlines.

Donor

The donor is the person making the LPA and choosing other people to make decisions on their behalf. Only the donor can make decisions about their LPA, such as choosing their attorneys. A donor must be at least 18 years old and have mental capacity when they make their LPA.
glossary:E:
Exemption

If the donor gets certain means-tested benefits, they can apply not to pay the fee to register their LPA. This is known as an ‘exemption’. Also see ‘remission’.
glossary:H:
Hardship application

Donors who cannot prove they are eligible for a remission or exemption can write to the Public Guardian explaining why paying for their LPA would cause them financial difficulty. This is known as a hardship application.
glossary:I:
Independent witness

If a donor cannot sign their LPA due to disability, they can appoint an authorised signatory to sign on their behalf. The signature must be witnessed by an independent witness, as well as by the donor’s certificate provider.
glossary:J:
Jointly

When a donor chooses to appoint their attorneys ‘jointly’, it means the attorneys must agree and must act together (‘jointly’) on all decisions, however big or small. For example, if money needs to be withdrawn from a bank, not only must all attorneys agree with this decision, but they must also be physically present when the money is withdrawn.

Learn more about how attorneys make decisions.

Jointly and severally

When a donor chooses to appoint their attorneys ‘jointly and severally’, it means the attorneys must agree on all decisions but can act together (‘jointly’) or on their own (‘severally’).

For example, if money needs to be withdrawn from a bank, one of the attorneys can perform this task on their own. The other attorneys must all agree to withdraw the money, but they don’t have to be physically present.

Learn more about how attorneys make decisions.

Jointly for some decisions, and jointly and severally for other decisions

With this option, the donor chooses to appoint their attorneys ‘jointly for some decisions, and jointly and severally for other decisions’. The attorneys must agree on all decisions, must act together (‘jointly’) for some decisions but can act together or on their own (‘jointly and severally’) for other decisions.

Learn more about how attorneys make decisions.
glossary:L:
Lasting power of attorney

An LPA is a legal document that allows the donor to choose other people to make decisions on their behalf. There are 2 types of LPA.

A property and affairs LPA covers decisions about the donor’s money, bills, benefits and home ownership. The donor decides whether this LPA should be used as soon as it is registered, or only when they have lost mental capacity.

A personal welfare LPA covers decisions about the donor’s day-to-day needs, health care, where they live, and their medical treatment. By law, it can only be used when the donor has lost mental capacity.

An LPA must be registered by the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) before it can be used.

Learn more about the 2 types of LPA.

Life-sustaining treatment

Life-sustaining treatment is any care, medicine, surgery or other remedy that a doctor says is needed to keep the donor alive.

If the donor makes a personal welfare LPA, they must decide whether to give their attorneys the power to allow or refuse life-sustaining treatment on their behalf. Decisions on life-sustaining treatment can only be made by others if the donor does not have mental capacity.

If the donor has an advance decision (opens in new tab), it’s important it isn’t contradicted by their decision about life-sustaining treatment.

Learn more about life-sustaining treatment.
glossary:M:
Mental capacity

A person with mental capacity is able to make a specific decision at the time it needs to be made. They will have at least some understanding of:

  • the decision they need to make
  • why they need to make it
  • any information relevant to the decision
  • what is likely to happen when they make it

Learn more about mental capacity.

Mental Capacity Act

The Mental Capacity Act (MCA) 2005 (opens in new tab) covers people in England and Wales who can’t make some or all decisions for themselves because they lack mental capacity. The MCA is intended to protect vulnerable individuals and ensure decisions are made in their best interests.
glossary:N:
Notice of intent to register

When OPG has completed checks on a donor’s signed and submitted LPA, we send a notice of intent to register to the donor, their attorneys, their replacement attorneys and any people the donor has chosen to notify. A 4-week waiting period then begins. This is required by law, to allow anyone with objections to raise them.

Notice of registration

At the end of the statutory 4-week waiting period to allow objections to be raised to the LPA, OPG registers the LPA. We send a notice of registration to the donor, their attorneys and their replacement attorneys.
glossary:O:
Office of the Public Guardian (OPG)

OPG is the agency in England and Wales that registers LPAs and protects people who do not have mental capacity.

OPG

Acronym for Office of the Public Guardian.
glossary:P:
People to notify

The donor can choose people to be told when the applicant applies to register the LPA. We call these ‘people to notify’. Having people to notify is optional.

People to notify provide extra security as they get a chance to raise any concerns about the LPA before it’s registered – for example, if they believe the donor has been put under pressure to make it.

Public Guardian

The Public Guardian is the chief executive of the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG). You can find details of the current Public Guardian by visiting OPG’s governance page (opens in new tab).
glossary:R:
Registration

An LPA must be registered with OPG before it can be used. The following steps must be completed before registration.

  1. The LPA must be filled in and signed by the donor, witnessed by the certificate provider.
  2. The LPA must be submitted to OPG, so we can check it’s been made correctly and there’s nothing that would make it invalid or unworkable.
  3. OPG will ask the certificate provider to provide a certificate for the LPA, and the attorneys to sign the LPA.
  4. OPG will inform any people the donor has asked us to notify.
  5. A 4-week waiting period will begin – this is required by law, to allow anyone with objections to raise them.
  6. If no objections are raised, the LPA will be registered by OPG.

Remission

If the donor has an income of less than £12,000 a year before tax, they can apply to pay less to register their LPA. This is known as a ‘remission’. Also see ‘Exemption’.

Replacement attorneys

Replacement attorneys are people the donor chooses to step in if one or more of their attorneys can no longer act or make decisions.

Replacement attorneys cannot act without the authorisation of the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG).
glossary:S:
Severance

If one or more of the restrictions or conditions a donor has added to an LPA are contradicted by their other instructions, or are illegal, the LPA will not work. An LPA cannot be amended once it has been signed by the donor, so it’s usually quicker to make a new LPA – OPG charges a reduced fee for this if the application is made within 3 months.

However, if the donor does not wish to make an LPA, or has lost mental capacity OPG can apply to the Court of Protection. The court has the power to ‘sever’ the restriction or condition which is stopping the LPA from working. It can then be used by the donor’s attorneys.
glossary:T:
Trust corporation

A trust corporation can be an attorney on a property and affairs LPA. A trust corporation manages the donor’s funds, including savings, pensions or investments. A trust corporation is usually run by a commercial bank or firm of solicitors. The donor cannot appoint more than one trust corporation in their LPA.
glossary:V:
Vouching

If the donor can’t confirm their identity using GOV.UK One Login, they can ask someone they know well to vouch for them. The person they ask must be able to confirm their own identity using GOV.UK One Login, and must then sign a declaration verifying the donor’s identity.
glossary:W:
Witness

Witnesses are impartial people who watch the attorneys and any replacement attorneys sign the LPA. The witnesses must also sign the LPA to say they’ve seen the attorneys and replacement attorneys sign.
